Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Complement System Modulation in Lung Transplantation

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised controlled trial included adults eligible for lung transplantation

Participants.evidence: Conducted at a tertiary care center, this randomised controlled trial included adults eligible for lung transplantation.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either a complement inhibitor or standard care.

Objective.evidence: To determine the effect of complement inhibition on lung transplant outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of primary graft dysfunction (PGD) within 72 hours post-transplant.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, 100 to the intervention and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group demonstrated a significant reduction in PGD incidence (mean difference = 15%, 95% CI 5% to 25%; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group experiencing gastrointestinal side-effects.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
